p.s: The excerpt uses a panoramic description of DelaneysDelaney's surroundings (ll. 33,34) through reported thought, where in he repeatedly referrsrefers to his own (l. 33,34).
This underlines DelaneysDelaney's indignation and builds up to the phrase You don't belong here (l. 39), which is a typical for a covert or open racist, who believes himself to be better than others.
It also contains symbolysmsymbolism since Delaney thinks of the CherrystonesCherrystone's lawn (l. 36) but would not mind seeing José deported either.
This is made clear by the narrator, who comments on the force of the shock, which Delaney gets, when he realizes that the trespasser is mexicanMexican (l. 17).
Apart from this the narrator describes José in an almost magical way, when Delaney first spots him (l. 10,11).
This also shows that the narrator builds up the tension in unison with DelaneysDelaney's rage, since the beginning of the scene has an exageratedexaggerated peaceful and almost magical atmosphere.
Furthermore the narrator goes on by using reported thought to show how DelaneysDelaney's mood immediately changes, once he sees that the man is Mexican (ll. 16-17).
At once he is more alert and already he starts to get angry which is shown by the unfriendly way in which he adresses José (ll. 17,18).
DelaneysDelaney's rage gets stronger throughout the scene, which is caused by the mocking of José and DelaneysDelaney's helplessnes (l. 33).
On the one hand this is shown through comments by the narrator, such as before he could think (l. 42) where he shows that Delaney acts on a racist and irrational impulsimpulse.
On the other hand the build up of rage is shown through many climaxes.
This is the case when Delaney insults José and calls him a thief, a liar [...] and finally a Mexican (ll. 50,51).

Apart from the tension, DelaneysDelaney's racism also becomes stronger in unison with his rage, which is shown when José starts getting annoyed and Delaney immediately supectssuspects that he has a knife or a gun (l. 54,55).

The tension builds up to a breaking point while Delaney speculates about whether or not he is about to be killed, until José presents one of the fliesflyers as evidence that he is innocent (ll. 55-59).
In the last paragraph Delaney is shown as devastated and shocked by himself (ll. 60f).
The narrator shows this through an inner monologue.
This conveys that there is a change of the roles of José and Delaney.
In the beginning José is shown as the victim through comments by the narrator (l. 42).
However at the end of the excerpt Delaney is cast into the role of the victim, who believes that he is to be pitied since he has been mocked by José and driven into an unwanted rage (ll. 60-65).
In conclusion, the narrator uses a lot of climaxes and streams of conciousness to show build up of DelaneysDelaney's rage, which also builds up tensions in unison.
